awd_titl_txt: A Symmetry-Based Approach to Minimum Energy Pathways
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical description: Symmetry is a powerful tool in all of physical sciences. Distortions, often a collection of atomic trajectories, are important for understanding a range of kinetic materials processes where atoms move under external stimuli such as fields, temperature, and stress. Predicting which path a material would take in undergoing a distortion is important for any application which involves such atomic motion. However, predicting such paths, called minimum energy pathways (MEPs), is currently stochastic in nature, and one can never be sure of the final results. This project aims at developing a new symmetry-based framework and computational tools through the introduction of new ideas such as distortion-reversal symmetry and distortion groups; it significantly improves the speed, numerical accuracy, and the comprehensive nature of search for such paths. Experimental verification of the theory predictions is the other aspect of this research. The growing need for educational training in computation materials research is being addressed with hands-on workshops in density-functional theory, active mentoring of undergraduates in research including women and underrepresented groups, and through active participation in STEM Academy of the Upward Bound Math and Science Program, as well as Penn State Millennium Scholars Program that attracts and guides talented STEM students to the undergraduate program. 

Technical description: This is an integrated theory-experimental proposal that develops new symmetry ideas and computational tools to explore minimum energy pathways (MEPs) for distortions, and more specifically, for ferroelectric domain switching and domain wall motion. The MEPs are computed by the Nudged Elastic Band method (NEB); however, it currently relies on a combination of stochastic process and user intuition to construct initial paths. The principal investigators are focused on the concept of the symmetry group of a path and are develop a code (to be made publicly available when ready) to implement these ideas in Quantum Espresso, an open-source density functional theory (DFT) software. Three model system classes are picked, namely, in simple perovskites, in layered oxides, and in multiferroics, to make predictions. The predicted MEPs with this approach are tested using the experimental techniques that push in-situ dynamics with 2-5 picometers metrology in electron microscopy, and ultrafast electron diffraction microscopy techniques.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit:

The language of symmetry and the mathematical tools in group theory that formalize it form the foundation of physical sciences. In materials science, these tools involve crystallography where the number of ways matter arranges in space and time are enumerated into space groups and spatio-temporal groups. Neumann’s principle states that the properties of an object (a collection of atoms, for example) must at least exhibit the symmetry of the object (underlying atomic arrangement, for example). This powerful principle uniquely ties physical phenomena to the underlying structure of matter. This project focused on one particular symmetry operation called antisymmetry, which is also called a 2-color symmetry or black and white symmetry.  This is a particularly important class of symmetries in physical sciences. One of the best known antisymmetries with respect to point groups is the spatial inversion that inverts all of space inside out about a single point.  Another very important antisymmetry is time-reversal, that reverses the flow of time.  As examples of their widespread utility, all polar materials have broken inversion symmetry, while all magnetically ordered materials have broken time-reversal symmetry.   The universe as a whole has Charge-Parity-Time (CPT) symmetry, implying that all laws of physics will be conserved, if, simultaneously, all of the space was inverted inside out (P, which is the same as inversion), all time flow was reversed (T, which is the same as time-reversal), and all particles charges were flipped from positive-to-negative and negative-to-positive (C denotes this charge conjugation). 

In this NSF-funded project, we have developed three new antisymmetries of relevance to materials science, as well as more broadly, to all physical sciences.  Distortion-reversal symmetry, reverses the direction of motion of atoms (for example) of a general distortion where atoms move from one state of configuration to another. This antisymmetry has been used to find the minimum energy pathways (MEPs) that a system will follow in going from one state to another.  This includes classical as well as quantum particles in a potential well.  An open-source software called Distortion Symmetry in Python (DiSPy) has been developed and released to calculate such MEPs (doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevB.98.085107). Another antisymmetry, wedge reversion, enables the classification of all physical quantities in arbitrary dimensions (doi.org/10.1107/S205327332000217X). We also proposed a spacetime transformation that transforms the hyberbolic geometry of relativistic spacetime into a Euclidean form.  A new antisymmetry called spacetime reversal was proposed, and the symmetry groups of crystals were thus mapped to discrete spacetime crystal symmetries (doi.org/10.13140/RG.2.2.31083.57126).  The transformation is now being explored for solving problems in quantum field theory. Two of the above antisymmetries have been reviewed in a review article by our team (doi.org/10.1146/annurev-matsci-100219- 101404). 

Broader Impact:

Three graduate students have earned their PhDs. One current graduate student (a woman) is working on finishing up publications.  One postdoc was partially supported. Three undergraduates performed their research.  One of the undergraduates contributed to co-author publications and is now a graduate student in Physics at Harvard. Another undergraduate (a woman) gave a presentation at the American Physical Society and is a graduate student in Chemistry at berkeley. A third undergraduate student (underrepresented group) is planning to apply for graduate school. Every summer, outreach activities were conducted for high school students called make-it-matter, focused on light-matter interactions.  The PI has also engaged in symmetry related outreach activities through demonstration of the Kolam artform in the local public library, and at the international children’s festival, and Asian pacific Islander heritage month celebration downtown.
